level.text: The Criminal Division of the Superior Court may issue process for the arrest of a person against whom an indictment is returned, an information is filed, or a complaint under oath is made.
be under the seal of the court;
bear teste in the name of a judge of the court, and
be signed by a clerk or employee of the court authorized to administer oaths.

In cases arising out of violations of any of the ordinances of the District of Columbia, process shall be directed to the Chief of Police, who shall execute the process and make return thereof in like manner as in other cases.
In all other criminal cases, the process issued by the Superior Court may be directed to the United States marshal or to the Chief of Police.
For services pursuant to subsection (d) of this section the marshal shall receive the fees prescribed by section 15-709(b).

level.heading: Legislative History of Law 12-81
level.text: Law 12-81, the "Technical Amendments Act of 1998," was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 12-408, which was referred to the Committee of the Whole. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on November 4, 1997, and December 4, 1997, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on December 22, 1997, it was assigned Act No. 12-246 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 12-81 became effective on March 24, 1998.
